newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: First National fuelled by fresh sale talk.
newsitem.headline: First National fuelled by fresh sale talk.

text.p: Fresh market talk that Anglo American Corp of South Africa could sell their First National Bank stake thrust the bank's share upward in active trade on Friday, dealers said.
"It's continued rumours that Anglo is selling their FNB stake," one dealer said.

FNB shares jumped to a day's high of 31 rand before retreating slightly to 30.75 rand by 1518 GMT from a previous close of 29.75 rand -- 100 cents or 3.36 percent higher -- in a traded volume of 672,100 shares.
Last Tuesday shares set a touched a year high of 32.50 rand, fuelled by the same sale talk.
Dealers said Anglo selling its 20.4 percent FNB stake was good news for the share because it would take account of the net asset value instead of current stock performance.
"FNB have underperformed this year so the share has been knocked. The deal would be closer to the net asset value than the current share price," a dealer said.
Hard hit by steep bad debts, the bank reported a meagre eight percent rise in 1996/97 annual earnings and is expected to repeat this when it reports interims on May 7.
Nedcor Ltd, Barclays of the UK, Hong Kong Shanghai Bank and Investec Ltd have all been suggested as possible buyers for Anglo's stake.
